newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Nov single-family home sales rose 14.2 pct.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Nov single-family home sales rose 14.2 pct.

text.p: U.S. Commerce Department reported sales of new single-family homes, seasonally adjusted, with percent changes from prior months (numbers in 1,000s).
- Pct----Nov Oct--Rev from Sept--Rev from
-By Region: Pct----Nov Oct--Rev from Sept--Rev from
Total November sales of single-family homes rose 13.7 percent from an annualized rate of 679,000 units a year ago.
In 1,000s: Nov Oct--Rev from Sept--Rev from
Actual Units Sold 53 54 57 62 63
Note-Actual number of new single-family units sold is not seasonally adjusted.
Wall Street economists had expected November single-family home sales at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 731,000 units.
The department also revised monthly percent changes of total sales, seasonally adjusted, from prior months as follows:
- Oct-Rev from Sept--Rev from Aug--Rev from
The annualized sales rate for August was revised to 820,000 units from 819,000.
The department said the 14.2 percent jump in November single-family home sales was the steepest since a 16.6 percent increase in April 1993.
Home sales in the Northeast rose 40.3 percent in November, the sharpest rise since a 67.4 percent increase in December 1995, it said.
The 10.2 percent rise in home sales in the South was the highest since a 28.7 percent increase in July 1995.
The November supply of homes for sale fell to 5.2 months' worth from a revised 5.9 months' worth in October that was previously reported as 5.6 months.
The inventory of houses for sale at the end of November was 328,000 units, down from a revised 332,000 units in October that was previously reported as 336,000 units.
